Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Sperm use and strategic sperm allocation in a Hawaiian swordtail cricket
Award.AbstractNarration: In many species, females mate with more than one male. This leads to sperm competition, where the sperm of several males compete to fertilize a female's eggs. All else equal, males that provide more sperm are expected to gain more fertilizations. However, the number of times a female mates and the extent to which she uses each male's sperm equally to fertilize her eggs also affect the number of fertilizations a given male is likely to achieve. Because sperm production entails a physiological cost, males are therefore expected to allocate different numbers of sperm to different females. In order to make predictions about these patterns in any species, investigators need information about how frequently females mate and how they use sperm. This research will provide that information for a species of Hawaiian cricket and will use it to predict patterns of male sperm allocation in this species. To determine female mating rate, individually marked females will be observed daily under semi-natural field conditions for ten weeks. To determine patterns of sperm use, the investigators will collect eggs daily and use genetic tools to identify the sires. These data will be corroborated in wild females by estimating, again using genetic tools, the number of mates and sires contributing to their sperm stores and offspring. This work will provide information on the sexual selection parameters operating in the field, crucial data that are rarely collected. The researchers will conduct outreach in Hawaii, in upstate New York by participating in a day of science education at a correctional facility for girls, and at Cornell by hiring an undergraduate research assistant from an underrepresented group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sexual selection occurs when some individuals are more successful than others in attracting mates and, in the case of males, siring offspring. If some males attract more mates than others, the resulting selection is termed precopulatory, since it is determined before copulation. If some males are more successful than others at siring offspring once they mate, the resulting selection is termed postcopulatory, since it is determined after (or during) copulation. Precopulatory sexual selection is a well studied process and has been shown to be very important in driving evolution in the wild. Postcopulatory sexual selection, on the other hand, while the subject of an increasing amount of laboratory-based research, has rarely been measured under natural conditions. Consequently, the importance of this type of selection compared to precopulatory sexual selection remains unclear.

This research aimed to evaluate the causes and consequences of postcopulatory sexual selection in a native Hawaiian cricket. The project had three main components: (1) Postcopulatory selection was quantitatively measured under semi-natural conditions, in a large field enclosure, through a combination of extensive behavioral observations and paternity analysis using genetic tools. (2) These measurements were corroborated in a natural population by using genetic tools to estimate both the number of males wild females mated with and the number of males that actually sired their offspring. (3) The resulting data were incorporated into a mathematical model predicting the optimal value of one postcopulatory sexual trait in particular, strategic sperm allocation, whereby males provide more or less sperm to different females depending on the mating context. The predictions of this model were tested in the study species by evaluating the species’ actual pattern of sperm allocation.

Overall, the results of this research point to a major role for postcopulatory sexual selection, which was found to have more potential than precopulatory sexual selection to drive evolution in the study species. Several aspects of the species’ mating behavior contribute to this finding: most females mate with more than one male; many males that mate with a given female fail to sire any of her offspring; and, among males that do sire offspring, paternity is significantly skewed, with some males having more than their fair share and others having fewer. Furthermore, postcopulatory sexual selection appears to have shaped male sperm allocation in exactly the way that would be expected given the conditions of this species, as the optimal allocation predicted by the mathematical model matches the actual allocation that was observed. The model also accurately predicted sperm allocation in two other species for which all of the relevant data were available.

The researchers conducted outreach by participating in a day of science education at a correctional facility for girls in upstate New York.
